title: Thomas Carney (Canadian politician)
text:
Thomas Carney (ca 1830 – 1905) was an <a href="United%20States">American</a>-born inventor and political figure in <a href="Manitoba">Manitoba</a>, Canada. He represented <a href="Emerson%20%28electoral%20district%29">Emerson</a> from 1880 to 1883 in the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Manitoba">Legislative Assembly of Manitoba</a> as a <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Manitoba">Conservative</a>.
He was born in <a href="Bradford%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Bradford County, Pennsylvania</a> and was educated there. Carney married Mary Ann Kaufelt. In 1873, he came to Manitoba and, with William Newton Fairbanks, founded the town of <a href="Emerson%2C%20Manitoba">Emerson</a>. Carney was mayor of Emerson from 1880 to 1883. He was elected to the Manitoba assembly in an 1880 by-election held after <a href="William%20Nash%20%28Manitoba%20politician%29">William Nash</a> was named registrar. While in Emerson, he developed an idea for a "coin changer" (<a href="cash%20register">cash register</a>). In 1884, he left Emerson to join the <a href="NCR%20Corporation">National Cash Register</a> company. Carney died in <a href="Dayton%2C%20Ohio">Dayton, Ohio</a>.
